"**How Far I 'll Go**" is a song from
[Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney Animation
Studios")'s 2016 animated feature film _[Moana](/wiki/Moana_\(2016_film\)
"Moana \(2016 film\)")_. It was written and produced by [Lin-Manuel
Miranda](/wiki/Lin-Manuel_Miranda "Lin-Manuel Miranda").[1] The song was
performed in the film by American actress and singer [Auliʻi
Cravalho](/wiki/Auli%CA%BBi_Cravalho "Auliʻi Cravalho") in her role as
[Moana](/wiki/Moana_\(Disney_character\) "Moana \(Disney character\)"). It was
released along with the album on November 18, 2016. Canadian singer [Alessia
Cara](/wiki/Alessia_Cara "Alessia Cara") also recorded the song for the
[_Moana_ soundtrack](/wiki/Moana_\(soundtrack\) "Moana \(soundtrack\)"). The
song was nominated for [Best Original
Song](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Academy Award for Best
Original Song") at the [89th Academy Awards](/wiki/89th_Academy_Awards "89th
Academy Awards") and [Best Original
Song](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Golden Globe Award for
Best Original Song") at the [74th Golden Globe
Awards](/wiki/74th_Golden_Globe_Awards "74th Golden Globe Awards") but lost
both to "[City of Stars](/wiki/City_of_Stars "City of Stars")" from _[La La
Land](/wiki/La_La_Land_\(film\) "La La Land \(film\)")._

##
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=How_Far_I%27ll_Go&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Composition")]

"How Far I'll Go" was composed as Moana's ["I Want"
song](/wiki/%22I_Want%22_song ""I Want" song"), following in the long
tradition of "I Want" songs in 1990s Disney animated musicals.[2][3] It
replaced an earlier attempt called "More", for which the
[demo](/wiki/Demo_\(music\) "Demo \(music\)") version recorded by [Marcy
Harriell](/wiki/Marcy_Harriell "Marcy Harriell") was released as an outtake on
the deluxe version of the soundtrack album. Although Miranda has stressed that
he is still "very proud of" the song as a first draft, "More" was not good
enough in retrospect because it merely expressed Moana's vague desire to see
more since she had already figured out everything about the island.[2][3] In
contrast, "How Far I'll Go" expresses a deeper, richer message: Moana's
struggle with the irresistible impulse to explore beyond the reef
notwithstanding her genuine love for her island, her family, and her
people.[2][3] As Miranda explained to _[People](/wiki/People_\(magazine\)
"People \(magazine\)")_ : "To me that's much more complicated than, 'I hate it
here and I want to get out,' ... To say, ‘I love it here, I love my parents,
but why can't I stop walking to the ocean and fantasizing about getting out of
here?' And questioning that instinct? It's even more confusing. And that's a
valid story too."[3]

To make himself write a song more compelling than "More", Miranda "[went
method](/wiki/Method_acting "Method acting")".[2] According to Miranda, he
locked himself in his childhood bedroom at his parents' residence for an
entire weekend in order to force his mind back to age 16 (the same age as
Moana in the film), a time when he was facing what seemed like an "impossible
distance" between the reality of his pleasant middle-class childhood which had
no connection to show business whatsoever, and his dreams of a career in show
business.[2] He was well aware that he was composing the next Disney "I Want"
song after "[Let It Go](/wiki/Let_It_Go_\(Disney_song\) "Let It Go \(Disney
song\)")" and that whatever he wrote had to be different from "Let It Go".[2]

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=How_Far_I%27ll_Go&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Music video")]

A music video for the song was released on December 12, 2016.[4]

## Other
languages[[edit](/w/index.php?title=How_Far_I%27ll_Go&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Other languages")]

When the movie had its first theater release worldwide, the song numbered 44
versions, including a special [Tahitian](/wiki/Tahitian_language "Tahitian
language")-language adaptation created specifically for the movie.[5] For
promotional purposes, [South African](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa")
singer [Lira](/wiki/Lira_\(singer\) "Lira \(singer\)")[6] and
[Filipino](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") singer and actress [Janella
Salvador](/wiki/Janella_Salvador "Janella Salvador")[7] recorded their own
English-language versions of the song in order to play them over the end
credits on the South African and Filipino release of the film, while
[Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia") singer [Maudy
Ayunda](/wiki/Maudy_Ayunda "Maudy Ayunda") and [Malaysian](/wiki/Malaysia
"Malaysia") singer Ayda Jebat recorded their own versions of the song
respectively in [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_language "Indonesian
language")[8] and [Malaysian](/wiki/Malaysian_language "Malaysian
language")[9] language.

On December 15, a 5-languages mash-up was released online, featuring singers
from [Southeast Asian](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia") countries:
[Janella Salvador](/wiki/Janella_Salvador "Janella Salvador") from the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), [Maudy
Ayunda](/wiki/Maudy_Ayunda "Maudy Ayunda") from [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia
"Indonesia"), [Myra Molloy](/wiki/Myra_Molloy "Myra Molloy") from
[Thailand](/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"), Ayda Jebat from
[Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia") and Trần Minh Như from
[Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam "Vietnam").[10] Shortly thereafter, a 24-languages
video was released on Disney's Vevo channel.[11]

In June 2017, a [Māori-language](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language "Māori language")
version of the movie, featuring four voice-actors from the original English
cast, was announced.[12] Three weeks later, [New Zealander](/wiki/New_Zealand
"New Zealand") Jaedyn Randell was introduced as Moana's singing voice. The
movie was released in September 2017.[13] In the same year, Shruti Rane
([Hindi](/wiki/Hindi "Hindi")) reprised her role in the [Bengali-
language](/wiki/Bengali_language "Bengali language") version of the movie.

In November 2017, a [Hawaiian-language](/wiki/Hawaiian_language "Hawaiian
language") dubbing was announced to be under way, with Auliʻi Cravalho
reprising her role as Moana.[14]

Canadian singer and songwriter [Alessia Cara](/wiki/Alessia_Cara "Alessia
Cara") recorded "How Far I'll Go" for the [_Moana_
soundtrack](/wiki/Moana_\(soundtrack\) "Moana \(soundtrack\)"), with the song
being released ahead of the soundtrack on October 28, 2016.[25]

### Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=How_Far_I%27ll_Go&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ 's Brittany Spanos
called the song "inspirational and sweet" and went on to say "the uplifting
song is a perfect fit into the _Disney_ canon, with Cara belting lyrics about
persevering to achieve her dreams in spite of her imperfections or
detractors."[26] US magazine _[Rap-Up](/wiki/Rap-Up "Rap-Up")_ said "the
empowering anthem allows the Canadian songstress to deliver outstanding vocals
about overcoming adversity to reach for goals" and labeled it "a song with a
message" and an "emotionally-charged track."[27] Taylor Weatherby of
_[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)")_ dubbed it
a "bouncy, uplifting tune."[1] [Idolator](/wiki/Idolator_\(website\) "Idolator
\(website\)")'s Mike Wass said "the inspiring anthem is the perfect antidote
to the general ugliness of 2016" and called it "a soaring ballad."[28]

### Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=How_Far_I%27ll_Go&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Music video")]

The official music video for the song, directed by [Aya
Tanimura](/wiki/Aya_Tanimura "Aya Tanimura"), was released on November 3,
2016.[29] Derek Lawrence of _[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly
"Entertainment Weekly")_ described the video: "The video finds Cara roaming an
empty beach as she belts out lyrics that reflect the film’s plot about a young
Polynesian girl setting sail for an epic adventure."[30] The video was filmed
at El Matador Beach in Malibu, California.[31]

the end credits. However, several localized adaptations of Cara's version of

markets around the world.
